intro.heading: Why Use a Step Up SIP Calculator
paragraphs: A Step Up SIP Calculator helps you project how an automated annual increase in your SIP contributions accelerates wealth creation.
Unlike a regular SIP where the monthly amount stays constant, a step-up SIP increases your instalment by a fixed percentage each year (for example, +10% annually).
This mirrors real-life salary growth and makes long-term goals easier to reach without large upfront changes to your budget.
The calculator converts your starting monthly SIP, annual step-up rate, expected fund return (CAGR) and tenure into a clear maturity value, total invested, and total gains.

Use it to plan goal-based investing (home, child education, retirement), to decide a comfortable initial SIP amount, and to visualise how modest annual top-ups compound into substantial wealth over time.

whatIs.heading: What is a Step Up SIP? — Step Up SIP Calculator Context
paragraphs: A Step Up SIP (also called top-up SIP) is a systematic investment plan where your monthly contribution increases at predetermined intervals—commonly once per year—by a fixed percentage or fixed amount.
For example, you may start with ₹5,000/month in year 1, then increase by 10% to ₹5,500/month in year 2, and continue the same rule in subsequent years.
The idea is to align savings with rising income: small incremental increases are easier to sustain than a big, one-time jump.
Unlike a one-time lump sum, step-up SIP preserves the rupee cost averaging benefit while adding the power of rising contributions.
Funds invested through Step Up SIPs stay invested and compound at the scheme’s returns, making this strategy powerful for long-term goals.
A Step Up SIP Calculator models this staged contribution schedule and shows the cumulative impact on your corpus.

formula.heading: How our Step Up SIP Calculator works — Logic, Formula & Assumptions
formula.intro: The calculator treats each year as a block where monthly contributions are constant within that year but increase by a factor (1 + g) each year (g = annual step-up rate). It compounds monthly contributions at the fund’s assumed annual return r (converted to a monthly rate i = r/12). Mathematically you can express the future value (FV) as a sum of future values of each year’s annuity:
definitions: r = Expected annual return (in decimal), i = r / 12
formula.note: The calculator sums each year’s contribution (grown by step-ups) and compounds it for the remaining period. It displays total invested, maturity (FV), and the implied CAGR. Assumptions such as step-up timing, compounding frequency, and return rate are transparently shown.

inputs.heading: What inputs you need — Ordered checklist for the Step Up SIP Calculator
inputs.intro: To run accurate projections, prepare these inputs in order:
list: Initial monthly SIP (PMT) — amount you’ll start investing.
Annual step-up rate (g%) — percent increase applied once per year.
Expected annual return (r%) — realistic CAGR assumption for the chosen mutual fund category.
Contribution timing — start month and whether step-up applies at year start or year end.
Optional: one-time lumpsum top-ups or employer contributions.
Optional: inflation or goal amount (to compute inflation-adjusted corpus or required SIP).
inputs.note: Enter these and the calculator produces maturity, total invested and breakdowns so you can test multiple plans quickly.

calculation.heading: Calculation formula (simple explanation) — Step-by-step formula & simplified view
calculation.intro: The Step Up SIP FV is the sum of future values for each year’s monthly annuity. Two representations are useful:

methods.title: 1) Exact sum (recommended):
formulas: For j = 0 to n−1 (year index), year-j monthly SIP = PMT × (1 + g)^j.
Each year’s 12 monthly contributions compound for 12(n − j) months at monthly rate i = r / 12:

methods.title: 2) Approximate continuous growth (fast estimate):
formulas: Treat step-up as a continuously growing annuity for a quick estimate; this is faster but less exact than the summation above.
Use the exact summation in the calculator for accuracy.

calculation.note: The calculator computes the exact summation numerically, so you don’t need to evaluate the series by hand.

example.heading: Illustrative example — Step Up SIP Calculator worked example
example.intro: Here’s a sample calculation to demonstrate how the Step Up SIP Calculator works in practice:
steps: Example: Start PMT = ₹5,000/month, g = 10% step-up annually, expected return r = 12% p.a., tenure n = 10 years.
Year-0 monthly SIP = ₹5,000; Year-1 = ₹5,500; Year-2 = ₹6,050; and so on as each year increases by 10%.
The calculator compounds each year’s twelve monthly deposits at the monthly rate i = 12% / 12 = 1%.
It then sums the future values of all contributions across years to compute the final corpus.
The results display total invested (sum of all monthly contributions), projected corpus, and total earnings.
You can observe how even small annual step-ups dramatically increase your final corpus compared to a flat SIP plan.
The calculator also provides a detailed year-by-year schedule to help you visualise the contribution growth.
example.note: This example highlights the compounding power of consistent yearly increases — a 10% annual step-up can lead to significantly higher wealth creation over long investment horizons.
